When it comes time to sell, providing this level of financial clarity (with history) reduces buyer uncertainty – often translating to a better valuation or smoother due diligence[sunbeltatlanta.com](https://www.sunbeltatlanta.com/blog/sell-your-roofing-business-tips-to-maximize-value#:~:text=Buyers%20will%20look%20closely%20at,several%20elements%2C%20including)[sunbeltatlanta.com](https://www.sunbeltatlanta.com/blog/sell-your-roofing-business-tips-to-maximize-value#:~:text=How%20Roofing%20Company%20Valuation%20Is,Calculated). Additionally, Spec-OS could enforce good practices like monthly close checklists, proper job costing entries, etc., effectively acting as a controller to keep the books due-diligence ready.
*   _Franchise-Ready Ops without Franchising:_ This phrase is essentially the value proposition of Spec-OS’s combined modules. By implementing Spec-OS fully, a roofing company should have **standardized operating procedures, a strong brand presence, reliable lead generation, automated training/onboarding (through stored SOPs and decision graphs), and detailed performance dashboards** – very akin to what a franchise system provides its franchisees. But here, the independent business gets those benefits via software, _retaining their independence and equity_. This is attractive to both owners (who improve their business) and to **strategic acquirers or PE** (who will pay a premium for a business that is turn-key with franchise-like systems in place). In fact, a strategic buyer might adopt Spec-OS across all their acquired locations to harmonize operations – making a Spec-OS-run company even more appealing.

**Embedding Valuation into Spec-OS:** The endgame is that Spec-OS doesn’t just help run the business; it helps _value_ and **sell** the business. Concretely, the platform could feature a **“Valuation Dashboard”** that is always accessible. This dashboard might show: _Current EBITDA_, _Estimated EV (enterprise value)_, and perhaps a breakdown like _“Based on current data, valuation is constrained by: owner dependency (moderate), recurring revenue (low), margin (good), growth trend (excellent)”_ – essentially grading the business on the key drivers (maybe pulled from something like the Matador driver model). The system could then operate almost like an **AI coach**, with interactive Q&A: “What can I do to improve my multiple?” and it would answer with tailored advice (pulling from the knowledge base and your data) – for example, _“Increase your maintenance contracts. Currently recurring revenue is only 5% of sales; companies that reach ~15% see higher multiples[sunbeltatlanta.com](https://www.sunbeltatlanta.com/blog/sell-your-roofing-business-tips-to-maximize-value#:~:text=While%20EBITDA%20is%20the%20standard,into%20a%20higher%20selling%20price). You could achieve this by converting 50 out of 1000 past customers onto an annual plan via an email campaign – shall I draft the email for you?”_ The AI can then _take action_ – since Spec-OS knows your CRM, it could even generate that campaign (Torch action). This tight integration means improving valuation isn’t a vague consulting report, but a set of concrete tasks in your workflow software. Every quarter, the system could even produce a **“valuation report”** similar to what BizBuySell does but far more customized – including comps from a Spec-OS user network if available, and adjusting for your specific metrics. As changes are made (with Torch and Takeoff implementing them), the improvements reflect in the valuation over time.

**Go-to-Market: Roofing First, Then Other Trades:** We plan to launch Spec-OS focusing on roofing companies as our beachhead market. Roofing has the right mix of size (tens of thousands of firms), pain points (seasonality, insurance, fragmented tech adoption), and current consolidation trends to make our offering timely. By developing the playbooks and AI models around roofing-specific data (terminology, workflows, KPIs), we ensure a tight product-market fit. Once proven in roofing, **expansion to HVAC and plumbing** (and other trades) is a logical next step. Not only are those industries similar in business model (field service, dispatch, maintenance contracts, etc.), but many contractors operate multi-trade companies (e.g. HVAC and plumbing together, or roofing and solar). Spec-OS’s modular design means we can **swap out the job libraries and diagnostics** for each trade while reusing the core platform. For instance, the Torch module for HVAC would emphasize reviews on Yelp and maintenance agreement marketing, while for roofing it emphasized weather events and Google search leads – but under the hood, it’s the same architecture. The financial and ops modules will be very similar (job costing for a roof vs. an AC install is conceptually alike). By creating these trade-specific templates (Spec-Kits) for each vertical, we can rapidly deploy into new markets. Our **go-to-market strategy** could involve partnering with industry associations or using thought leadership content (“How to double your HVAC business valuation”) to attract interest in those sectors after roofing.

**Strategic Fit:** Spec-OS’s approach aligns perfectly with the needs our research identified: contractors need **guidance and systems** to increase their business value, and currently they either don’t get it at all, or pay through the nose for consulting or ad-hoc tools. By building that guidance into the software they use daily, we not only differentiate Spec-OS from generic CRMs or accounting software, but we also create a virtuous cycle: the better they use Spec-OS, the more valuable their business becomes (which is highly motivating for owners). This could drive strong word-of-mouth in the industry: e.g. “I implemented Spec-OS and in 18 months my profits are up and my business appraised 50% higher.” That’s a powerful story. Additionally, by quantifying the impact of Spec-OS in terms of valuation (something owners ultimately care deeply about), we can justify premium pricing and build long-term customer loyalty (they have an incentive to keep using the system through an eventual sale and even encourage the buyer to continue with it).

In sum, Spec-OS has the chance to be the **operating system for value creation** in trades. It takes abstract concepts like “professionalize your business” and turns them into concrete steps and automated workflows. It spans the roles of CMO, CTO, CFO in a cohesive way – something no competitor does – and directly maps onto the factors that drive higher exit multiples. Launching in roofing maximizes our immediate impact (given the industry’s strong demand and consolidation activity), and once refined there, the template is ready to **scale to every home service vertical**, riding the wave of investment and interest in modernizing these “last mile” industries. Spec-OS will not only help owners run better businesses day-to-day, but uniquely will help them **build a sellable, high-value company** – effectively **software-izing the entire journey from startup to successful exit**.

7\. Appendix
------------

**Benchmark Multiples by Trade and Size:** The table below summarizes typical valuation multiples for contracting businesses (approximate ranges, for illustrative purposes):

| **Industry & Size** | **SDE Multiples** | **EBITDA Multiples** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Roofing Contractor (Small)** – owner-operated, ~$1M revenue, <$500K SDE. | **1.9× – 2.7×** SDE (average ~2.5×)[sunbeltatlanta.com](https://www.sunbeltatlanta.com/blog/sell-your-roofing-business-tips-to-maximize-value#:~:text=Image%3A%20Create%20a%20clean%20professional,demand%20markets)[buybizusa.com](https://buybizusa.com/value-my-roofing-company-worth/#:~:text=Sales%20Price%208%20%24450%2C000%20%244%2C500%2C000,25).  
_(Revenue multiple ~0.3× – 0.5×)_[peakbusinessvaluation.com](https://peakbusinessvaluation.com/valuation-multiples-for-a-roofing-company/#:~:text=Average%20REV%20Multiple%20range%3A%200,51x). | **2.5× – 3.6×** EBITDA (average ~3×)[sunbeltatlanta.com](https://www.sunbeltatlanta.com/blog/sell-your-roofing-business-tips-to-maximize-value#:~:text=Image%3A%20Create%20a%20clean%20professional,demand%20markets)[buybizusa.com](https://buybizusa.com/value-my-roofing-company-worth/#:~:text=Multiple%20of%20Revenue%208%200,25). |
| **Roofing Contractor (Mid-sized)** – well-established, $5–10M revenue, $1M+ EBITDA. | **3× – 4×** SDE likely (if using SDE) – but SDE less common at this scale. | **4× – 6×** EBITDA for many deals[linkedin.com](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/seanmshapiro_weather-dependent-markets-command-premium-activity-7394392784725581824-M6J6#:~:text=Florida%20roofing%20companies%3A%206.5,prone)[axiaadvisors.com](https://axiaadvisors.com/private-equity-in-roofing/#:~:text=Booming%20axiaadvisors,EBITDA%20for%20quality%20roofing). Exceptional cases up to ~7× if systems and growth are strong[industrypro.com](https://industrypro.com/industry_insight/there-is-no-normal-valuation-only-opportunity-to-prepare/#:~:text=,data%20and%20systems%20in%20place). Storm-prone market players lean high end (6–7×)[linkedin.com](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/seanmshapiro_weather-dependent-markets-command-premium-activity-7394392784725581824-M6J6#:~:text=Weather,replacement%20cycles%20%3D%20buyer%20confidence). |
| **HVAC Contractor (residential-focused)** – stable maintenance base, ~$5M revenue. | **5× – 7×** SDE (maintenance contracts boost SDE multiples higher than roofing)[firstpagesage.com](https://firstpagesage.com/business/hvac-ebitda-valuation-multiples/#:~:text=Company%20Type%20Specialization%20SDE%20Range,5x). | **7× – 9×** EBITDA common for mid-sized residential HVAC[firstpagesage.com](https://firstpagesage.com/business/hvac-ebitda-valuation-multiples/#:~:text=Company%20Type%20Specialization%20EBITDA%20Range,9x). Larger platforms even 10×+ EBITDA in recent hot market[linkedin.com](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/thomasbasch_roofing-growth-activity-7354182966241030144-o4Z0#:~:text=). _(HVAC multiples are generally higher due to recurring service revenue and buyer demand.)_ |
| **Plumbing Contractor** – similar to HVAC in many cases (if service-based). | **4× – 6×** SDE typical (plumbing service companies often ~4–5× SDE). | **6× – 8×** EBITDA is a typical range for mid-sized plumbing/HVAC (often grouped together by buyers). High recurring service revenue pushes toward upper end. |
| **Electrical Contractor (service)** – $2–5M revenue. | **3× – 5×** SDE (electricians see strong demand but also require licensing etc., so multiples vary). | **5× – 7×** EBITDA in many cases. Often somewhere between roofing and HVAC multiples depending on service vs new construction mix. |
| **General Contractor (residential construction)** – $10M revenue, project-based. | **2× – 3×** SDE if mostly new construction (lower due to cyclicality)[linkedin.com](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/thomasbasch_roofing-growth-activity-7354182966241030144-o4Z0#:~:text=listened%20to%20a%20majority%20of,sector%20of%20the%20roofing%20industry). | **3× – 5×** EBITDA (GCs building new homes or spec projects often have lower multiples unless they have maintenance or remodeling divisions). |

_Sources:_ Roofing multiples from Peak Business Valuation and broker data[sunbeltatlanta.com](https://www.sunbeltatlanta.com/blog/sell-your-roofing-business-tips-to-maximize-value#:~:text=Image%3A%20Create%20a%20clean%20professional,demand%20markets)[buybizusa.com](https://buybizusa.com/value-my-roofing-company-worth/#:~:text=Sales%20Price%208%20%24450%2C000%20%244%2C500%2C000,25); HVAC/Plumbing from FirstPageSage 2025 report (noting residential HVAC ~8× EBITDA average)[firstpagesage.com](https://firstpagesage.com/business/hvac-ebitda-valuation-multiples/#:~:text=The%20State%20of%20HVAC%20M%26A); GC/new construction insights from industry discussions[linkedin.com](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/thomasbasch_roofing-growth-activity-7354182966241030144-o4Z0#:~:text=listened%20to%20a%20majority%20of,sector%20of%20the%20roofing%20industry). These ranges are generalized; actual multiples depend on the individual company’s financials and qualitative factors as discussed.

**Public Roofing Companies as Comparables:** While no pure-play U.S. roofing contractors are publicly traded, there are large private firms and roll-ups that give a sense of “ceiling” valuations in the industry. **CentiMark**, for example, surpassed $1 billion in annual sales in 2021[centimark.com](https://www.centimark.com/component/easyblog/centimark-hits-1-billion-in-sales-for-commercial-roofing-flooring-1#:~:text=Flooring%20www,in%20sales%20through%20organic%20growth), making it one of the largest roofing contractors in North America. If we consider how such a company might be valued: large diversified contractors often trade in the **7×–9× EBITDA** range (similar to large facility services firms). CentiMark, Tecta America, and Flynn Group (Canada) have all received significant private equity investment over the years, indicating valuations far above the 3× multiples of small local roofers. These firms have national accounts, professional management, and scale efficiencies. For instance, anecdotally, some large platform deals in roofing have hit **6.5–7.5× EBITDA** for strong regional players, especially in growth markets[linkedin.com](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/seanmshapiro_weather-dependent-markets-command-premium-activity-7394392784725581824-M6J6#:~:text=Weather,replacement%20cycles%20%3D%20buyer%20confidence). The takeaway for a small business owner is that the more your company starts to resemble these big players in professionalism and systems (if not in size), the closer your multiple can inch toward what _they_ might get. Also, the consolidation led by these large companies can be an opportunity: being acquired by a platform like Tecta or a PE-backed entity can sometimes yield a premium if your company fills a strategic gap (location or client base) for them.

**Recent Acquisition Examples (BizBuySell & M&A):** To illustrate real-world outcomes: a Florida roofing business with ~$4M EBITDA was reportedly acquired by a PE firm at about **7× EBITDA with an earn-out**, due to its strong management and storm market position[industrypro.com](https://industrypro.com/industry_insight/there-is-no-normal-valuation-only-opportunity-to-prepare/#:~:text=,data%20and%20systems%20in%20place). On the smaller end, a Colorado roofing company doing $3M in sales and $415K SDE was listed at $400K (less than 1× SDE) to attract a quick sale[bizbuysell.com](https://www.bizbuysell.com/business-opportunity/3m-roofing-company-w-415k-profit-150-5-star-reviews/2385579/#:~:text=Asking%20Price%3A%20%24400%2C000)[bizbuysell.com](https://www.bizbuysell.com/business-opportunity/3m-roofing-company-w-415k-profit-150-5-star-reviews/2385579/#:~:text=sales%20process%20create%20a%20platform,with%20significant%20growth%20potential) – highlighting that not all sellers maximize value (in this case the owner was pursuing other ventures and priced for a fast exit). Most healthy small roofing companies, however, tend to _list_ around **2.5–3× SDE** (or equivalently 3.5–4.5× EBITDA if margins are typical)[bizbuysell.com](https://www.bizbuysell.com/business-opportunity/3m-roofing-company-w-415k-profit-150-5-star-reviews/2385579/#:~:text=sales%20process%20create%20a%20platform,with%20significant%20growth%20potential), and _sell_ somewhere slightly below that after negotiation. On BizBuySell, you’ll often see listings touting things like _“$2M Roofing Co. with $500K profit, Asking $1.3M”_ which is ~2.6× SDE. Businesses that can demonstrate upside (e.g. “built to scale, could franchise” etc.) try to push toward 3×+ SDE in asking price. For example, one listing in Utah highlighted as _“Multi-State Roofing Biz with Room to Raise the Roof”_ was asking $4.5M on about $1.2M cash flow – roughly **3.75× SDE**, presumably justified by its growth rate and multi-state operations[bizbuysell.com](https://www.bizbuysell.com/business-opportunity/thriving-multi-state-roofing-and-exterior-contractor/2324442/#:~:text=Thriving%20Multi,Cash).

**Matador’s Value Driver Model:** (From internal analysis) Matador Solutions uses a value driver scoring system to rate a business as _Below Avg, Average, or Above Avg_ in key areas, which correlates with the tiered multiples mentioned in Section 1. For roofing, the critical drivers include: **Management Independence**, **Financial Records Quality**, **Diverse Customer Base**, **Recurring Revenue**, **Market Outlook**, and **Operational Systems**. If a company scores “Above Average” in most categories, Matador’s model suggests it could achieve that ~7× EBITDA tier, which is **152% higher exit value** than an average company of the same size【44†】. This reinforces quantitatively that working on these drivers (exactly what we’ve detailed and what Spec-OS aims to facilitate) can more than double your company’s valuation.

In closing, the data and examples show the spectrum of outcomes: a well-prepared roofing company can be an extremely valuable asset – not only supporting a lucrative sale but also performing better in the meantime. By focusing on the value drivers and leveraging tools like Spec-OS to “level up” how the business is run, owners can position themselves to ride the ongoing consolidation wave in the trades sector and **achieve a premium exit when the time is right**.

Great I'd like to build a database of roofing businesses sold, at what valuation, what revenue, what ebitda, what SDE, what multiples, state city location, etc etc as much relevant data points as possible. Sources: internet, bizbuysell and other competitiors, etc. Can you do this for me?

## Response:
To get started on building your database of sold roofing businesses, could you clarify a few things:

1.  **Geographic Scope**: Do you want only U.S. sales, or include Canada or other countries?
2.  **Business Size Range**: Are you targeting all sizes (e.g., under $1M, $1M–$10M, $10M+), or just a specific band?
3.  **Timeframe**: Are you interested in all historical sales or just those from the past few years?
4.  **Competitor Platforms**: Should I include businesses from other trades (HVAC, plumbing, etc.) for context or focus strictly on roofing?
5.  **Output Format**: Do you want the data in spreadsheet/table format with columns for revenue, SDE, EBITDA, multiple, location, etc.?

With this info, I can start sourcing comparable sales data from BizBuySell, BizQuest, LoopNet, and other relevant platforms.

4. for now focus on roofing

**Table:** Selected U.S. roofing company transactions (2015–2025). “–” indicates not publicly reported. \*Ridgeline’s 2024 entry reflects its platform-creation investment by Bertram Capital. All other values (price, EBITDA, etc.) were undisclosed by press releases or news. (Sources cited per row.)

Roofing M&A has **spiked in recent years**, driven by strong market fundamentals. The U.S. roofing services market was about **$27.5B** in 2023, fragmented across thousands of local contractors (e.g. Florida alone has ~6,397 roofing businesses). Roofers are increasingly strategic targets: _private equity_ firms and strategic buyers have been active. For example, Morgan Stanley’s MSCP acquired Allstar Services (MN) in 2023, Bertram Capital built the Ridgeline platform with multiple tuck-in buys in 2024–25, and FirstService (TSX: FSV) acquired Atlanta’s Roofing Corp of America in late 2023[prnewswire.com](https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/soundcore-capital-partners-announces-sale-of-roofing-corporation-of-america-302017889.html#:~:text=add,We%20are%20pleased)[prnewswire.com](https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/soundcore-capital-partners-announces-sale-of-roofing-corporation-of-america-302017889.html#:~:text=Financial%20terms%20of%20the%20transaction,to%20Soundcore%20and%20Roofing%20Corp).

Valuation multiples vary by size and niche. TopBuild’s **$810M** acquisition of Progressive Roofing (Phoenix, AZ) in 2025 closed at **~9.1× EBITDA** – a premium reflecting Progressive’s large scale ($438M revenue, 70% recurring maintenance business) and market position. In contrast, most small and mid-market roofing deals (e.g. the Ridgeline or RRA acquisitions) do **not publicly report multiples**, but are generally thought to trade in the mid-single- to high-single-digit EBITDA range. Many of these platform deals are undisclosed in price (table entries “Undisclosed”), but advisors note the sector’s consolidation potential.

**Key trends:** As noted by Axia Advisors, roofing M&A has been “almost weekly”; 19 deals occurred in just Q1 2024, up ~116.7% from six years earlier. Buyers include both financial sponsors (e.g. Great Range Capital’s Roofed Right America bought Upstate NY, Colorado’s B&M, and CT/MA’s Eagle Rivet in 2023–2025[prnewswire.com](https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/roofed-right-america-acquires-upstate-roofing--painting-301977865.html#:~:text=Upstate%2C%20which%20celebrates%20its%2050,organization%20under%20the%20Upstate%20brand)[prnewswire.com](https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/roofed-right-america-expands-its-geographic-presence-with-investment-in-eagle-rivet-roof-services-302594332.html#:~:text=MILWAUKEE%2C%20Oct,area%20expanding%20throughout%20New%20England)) and large industry platforms (e.g. Nations Roof’s Midwest expansion with Boone Brothers[prnewswire.com](https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/nations-roof-acquires-boone-brothers-roofing-302617350.html#:~:text=BRASELTON%2C%20Ga,the%20transaction%20were%20not%20disclosed), Tecta America adding Texas Roofing[roofingcontractor.com](https://www.roofingcontractor.com/articles/101640-tecta-america-acquires-texas-roofing-commercial-contractor#:~:text=December%209%2C%202025)). The mix of buyers reflects the market: sophisticated PE groups (Morgan Stanley Capital Partners, Bertram, New State, etc.) and industry consolidators (FirstService, Nations, Tecta, TopBuild) are all pursuing roofing assets.

**Observations:** Notable outliers include TopBuild/Progressive (large, 9× EBITDA multiple) and the volume of roll-ups by platforms like Ridgeline and RRA. Recurring maintenance revenue is a prized asset (Progressive’s 70% non-discretionary revenue), and strong local brands help justify deals (e.g. Tecta preserved the “Texas Roofing” brand[roofingcontractor.com](https://www.roofingcontractor.com/articles/101640-tecta-america-acquires-texas-roofing-commercial-contractor#:~:text=December%209%2C%202025), Nations retained Boone’s legacy team[prnewswire.com](https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/nations-roof-acquires-boone-brothers-roofing-302617350.html#:~:text=Boone%20Brothers%20Roofing%2C%20founded%20in,applicator%20for%20major%20roofing%20manufacturers)). In storm-prone regions like the Southeast, ample replacement demand and thousands of small players make consolidation attractive. In summary, roofing is a **high-growth M&A segment** with favorable valuations for sellers, fueled by market fragmentation, recurring demand, and PE interest.

**Sources:** Transaction details are drawn from industry press releases and news (roofing trade magazines, PRNewswire, company IR), as cited above. Market trends are based on industry analyses and specific deal reports[prnewswire.com](https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/roofed-right-america-acquires-upstate-roofing--painting-301977865.html#:~:text=Upstate%2C%20which%20celebrates%20its%2050,organization%20under%20the%20Upstate%20brand). How to use this as an HR + valuation tool (simple, repeatable)
--------------------------------------------------------------

**1) Standardize your internal “position map.”**  
For each employee/role, map your job title to the closest SOC role above (e.g., “Crew Lead” → 47-1011).

**2) Compare pay to the market band (P25–P75).**

*   **Below market:** Company pay < P25
*   **Market:** P25 ≤ pay ≤ P75
*   **Premium:** pay > P75  
    Use hourly for field; annual for management/office when applicable.

**3) Add “fully loaded labor” (what buyers care about).**  
Create an internal loaded rate:

*   **Loaded Labor Cost = Base Wages + Employer Payroll Taxes + Workers’ Comp + Benefits**  
    This is the figure that drives **gross margin / EBITDA**, which directly impacts valuation.

**4) Flag valuation-relevant risks/opportunities.**

*   **Under-market foremen/supervisors** → churn risk, quality risk, rework, schedule slippage (buyer diligence red flags).
*   **Over-market without productivity metrics** → margin compression (lower EBITDA multiple).
*   **Premium pay + documented training/SOPs + low turnover** → supports “premium crew” narrative and de-risks continuity (multiple expansion story).
